titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Merrill Opera Video Collection ARS.0034
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Franz Kunst

publicationstmt.p: The Board of Trustees of Stanford University. All rights reserved.

profiledesc.descrules: Prepared using Describing Archives: a Content Standard

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.abstract: Unpublished opera productions on videocassette, from the collection of Greg Merrill Fe de Montreve.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research; material must be requested at least two business days in advance of intended use. Contact the Archive for assistance.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with repository. Publication and reproduction rights reside with the creators or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Head Librarian of the Archive of Recorded Sound.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Merrill Opera Video Collection, ARS-0034. Courtesy of the Stanford Archive of Recorded Sound, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

acqinfo.head: Source
acqinfo.p: The Merill Opera Video Collection was donated to the Stanford Archive of Recorded Sound by by the estate of Greg Merrill Fe de Montreve in 2004.

processinfo.head: Sponsor
processinfo.p: This finding aid was produced with generous financial support from the National Historical Publications and Records Commission.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unpublished opera productions on videocassette, from the collection of aficionado Greg Merrill Fe de Montreve. Featuring both live performances and filmed versions, the operas generally fall within the established canon; there are multiple works by Massenet, Offenbach, Verdi, Donizetti, Mozart, and Wagner. Several are from the Metropolitan Opera, but there are productions from around the world, with many familiar names in starring roles. In general, personnel and location are listed on cassettes. Some performances are in English translation. Few productions are dated precisely, although the majority are from the 1970s and 80s. Given the printed labels, most tapes were probably bought or traded from dealers, especially those assigned numbers. The Betamax cassettes all have handwritten labels, which suggest home recording. Titles are transcribed as on the labels.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Vagabond King ; Monte Carlo ; Love Me Tonight ; Jeanette on TV

scopecontent.p: Song O' My Heart, Concert Sequence ; CA Zephyr ; Verdi - Falstaff BBC 72 ; Ernani, Met 12/17/83 ; Ludwig Brahms Concert/Old Met Shorts ; Fortz - Caballe ; La Giaconda ; Broslovsky, Berlin Philharmonic ; Trains/Great Caruso ; Gayarre ; Moonlight Sonata/Paderewski ; I Sing For You Alone, Tito Schipa ; Don Carlo, Met Pt.2 1983 ; Centennial Met Gala 1983 ; Fidelio 1/78 ; Don Pasquale
